content:
The "Program Management Improvement Accountability Act" establishes governmentwide standards, policies, and guidelines for program and project management for executive agencies. The Deputy Director for Management is responsible for overseeing the implementation of these standards and policies, chairing the Program Management Policy Council, and engaging with the private sector to identify best practices. The "Program Management Improvement Accountability Act" mandates governmentwide standards, policies, and guidelines for program and project management. It includes conducting portfolio reviews, engaging with the private sector for best practices, and establishing a 5-year strategic plan. The Department of Defense is exempt if similar provisions are already in place. The Deputy Director for Management oversees implementation and chairs the Program Management Policy Council. The Deputy Director for Management of the Office of Management and Budget will issue standards, policies, and guidelines required under section 503(c) of title 31, United States Code. Regulations must be issued within 90 days to implement the requirements. Program Management Improvement Officers and Program Management Policy Council are established under section 1126 of title 31, United States Code. The Program Management Improvement Officer of each agency designated under section 1126 shall implement program management policies and develop strategies to enhance the role of program managers, including providing enhanced training opportunities. The Program Management Improvement Officer will provide training in relevant competencies for program and project managers in the private sector, emphasizing cost containment for large projects and programs. The curr_chunk discusses mentoring, career paths, recruitment, best practices dissemination, and tools for program management improvement within agencies. It also mentions that the provisions do not apply to the Department of Defense if similar to existing regulations. The Program Management Improvement Officer is designated by the Acquisition, Technology, and Logistics Under Secretary. The Program Management Policy Council, established in the Office of Management and Budget, serves as the main interagency forum for enhancing agency practices in program and project management. It advises the Deputy Director for Management, reviews high-risk programs, and discusses topics like career development and continuous improvement. The Program Management Policy Council advises on program and project management improvement, challenges, and standards governmentwide. It is composed of five members from the Office of Management and Budget. The Program Management Policy Council consists of five members from the Office of Management and Budget, including the Deputy Director for Management, the Administrator of the Office of Electronic Government, the Administrator of Federal Procurement Policy, the Controller of the Office of Federal Financial Management, and the Director of the Office of Performance and Personnel Management. The Program Management Policy Council is chaired by the Deputy Director for Management of the Office of Management and Budget. The Council meets at least twice per fiscal year and is supported by the head of each agency with a project. The head of each agency with a Project Management Improvement Officer provides administrative support to the Council upon request. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget must submit a report to Congress within one year of the Act's enactment. Program and Project Management Personnel Standards require regulations to be issued within 180 days of the standards, policies, and guidelines being issued. The Director of the Office of Personnel Management, in consultation with the Director of the Office of Management and Budget, will issue regulations to identify key skills and competencies, establish a new job series for program and project management, and create a new career path for managers within agencies. The Government Accountability Office will report on the effectiveness of policies on program and project management within 3 years of the Act's enactment.
